awd_titl_txt: AI Institutes Leadership Summit and Development of a Virtual Organization
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, UC Davis and Duke University organizing a series of annual leadership summits and constructing a virtual organization. These mutually supporting activities support the National Artificial Intelligence (AI) Research Institutes Program and its funding agencies by facilitating coordination, collaboration, and community-building across academia, government, and industry. The meetings and supporting organization aim to broaden the AI research community into a richly connected network of institutes and collaborators. These efforts serve the community of researchers funded by the AI Institutes program by establishing a collection point and collaboration platform enabling sharing of resources, programs, expertise, and best practices. The project also seeks to enhance coordination and dissemination between AI Institutes and the broader public by making the AI Institutes programs and personnel more accessible, disseminating institute outcomes, and promotion of AI Institute activities of interest to the broader community. The combined effect of leadership summits and a public-facing virtual organization will connect many researchers across a large and far reaching multisector national strategic AI initiative. These activities are central to achieving and transitioning AI innovations and creating a future AI-ready workforce beyond the confines of individual institute efforts and contribute significantly to U.S. leadership in AI.

Leadership summits are in the style of a PI meeting, but more aptly named to include institute key personnel more broadly. These meetings and the longer term coordination and collaboration among AI Institutes and the broader community are to be enabled by the establishment of a collaborative content management system for the sharing and dissemination of content and a public-facing web portal for access and broader engagement. All AI Institutes share the overarching goals to advance research in AI,  nurture the next generation of talent, and serve as nexus points for collaborative efforts. The annual meetings of key personnel and the enduring virtual organization are aimed at creating effective and lasting collaborative connections. Initial development of the virtual organization and its supporting portal focuses on content that informs the public and directs interested collaborators to the right institute personnel, promotes institute activities, outcomes, and events, and disseminates resources and opportunities arising from the institutes. Annual leadership summits provide the ideal opportunity for continuous evaluation and enhancement of these community building efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The NSF and USDA-NIFA funded 7 AI institutes in 2020, and an additional 11 institutes in 2021.  Cross-institute communications initially began organically in the community through self-organized monthly Zoom meetings of the PI’s called Directors Club meetings. Project/Program managers for each institute likewise established regular monthly meetings and set up Slack channels on topics, not only related to project management, but also communications, data management, and general discussions. AIVO was proposed and initiated to build upon the common interests among AI Institutes and to create a network among them. In this initial award, AIVO established this virtual organization with the rapid development of a website (aiinstitutes.org) . As promised in our timeline, we created and deployed the initial AIVO site within two months of starting its construction. This site for the first time collected institutes information and contacts into a single resource for use by the public, the funding agencies, and the institutes themselves to engage with these activities, and was a timely starting point for organizing the inaugural Summit of AI Institutes Leadership (SAIL) which was funded via this grant. We further enhanced the website with a newsfeed feature which amplified each institute’s communications and added an intra-web feature to allow for a private space for institutes to add events and view each other’s events. 

Via a joint effort of UC Davis and subawardee Duke University staff as program chairs, along with input from institutes and NSF, the conference program was developed based on regular committee meetings, so that a diversity of domains and speakers were represented. We were asked to provide hybrid meeting capabilities and we did so by coordinating with the local A/V contractor for Asilomar as well as assigning staff from UC Davis (the AIFS institute staff) to handle specific duties prior to, and during the conference. Main hall presentations and breakout room sessions were streamed via Zoom meeting sessions, and also recorded for later viewing on the NSF AIRC portal. Given that during the planning period of Spring ‘22 when it was still not 100% clear that the COVID threat would subside, we also reserved a backup facility for coordinating a streamed conference from a room UC Davis in case the entire conference needed to be held remotely. There were 165 registrants for SAIL 2022, with 130 attending in person and 35 attending via hybrid. 

We conducted a survey of attendees, with 130 questions asked, 35 of which provided a numerical score. From these 35 numerical scores starting with “How would you rate….”, with 1=unnecessary, 2=not good, 3=average, 4=good, and 5=great, the mean score was 4.24. The highest mean score was for dinner keynote speaker Erik Brynjolfsson’s talk “The Turing Trap: Promise and Peril of Human-like AI”. The lowest two scores(3.73 and 3.85) were for out-brief sessions. 

Broader Impacts  

This first  SAIL summit and VO portal at aiinstitutes.org provided a special opportunity for the first 18 institutes to collectively connect on many levels and across a timeframe longer than a single summit. The summit provided for thematic conversations and keynote speakers from outside the institutes, allowing for a leveling up of new institutes’ knowledge base and a cross-pollination among all institutes for how they address issues along the way.  

As shown in Figure 1, the first SAIL conference at Asilomar Conference Grounds in Pacific Grove, CA, from December 13-15, 2022, provided for a focused venue for establishing connections between the AI institutes.

Although not representative of all attendees, the photo nevertheless captures a broad swath of attendees, representing AI institute PI’s and staff, government funding agencies, and funding partners. AIVO established itself as a go-to organization for the national media (e.g., The New York Times) for contact and access. As shown in Figure 2, AIVO displays key news and media events on its home page, to further indicate to anyone landing on the page the power of this virtual organization. 

Between August 2022, the AIVO site traffic increased 287% and number of visitors increased 277%. The presence of AIVO on social media has helped to amplify AIVO activity and news. Our Twitter feed is now providing 18% of the amount of traffic that search engines deliver.

It is from this foundation of the first grant to establish AIVO, that significant expansion in programming was proposed going forward, to allow the national AI institutes to realize a greater impact through this network of networks.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 09/19/2024
Modified by: Stephen F Brown

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 2: The amplification loop that AIVO provides: Key news and events are posted on the aiinstitutes.org site, making the site more attractive and findable through various searches, which leads to more reach-outs.
    Phong Duong
    Public Domain
    Stephen F Brown
    AIVO's communications amplification loop
  • Figure 1: Group photo of SAIL 2022 attendees at Asilomar Conference Grounds, Pacific Grove, CA
    Phong Duong
    Public Domain
    Stephen F Brown
    SAIL 2022 attendees
